pageContext.title: 15 female founders in Southeast Asia who are smashing the glass ceiling
pageContext.content:
Studies have suggested that female-led businesses improve investors’ fund performance. They’ve also been found to outperform male-led companies by 63 percent in terms of investor returns.

Here’s a rosy picture: from 2009 to 2014, the number of US startups with at least one woman founder doubled from 9.5 percent to 18 percent, according to business information platform CrunchBase.

But if you take a closer look, you’ll spot some sobering details. From 2012 to 2017, for instance, the percentage of venture capital-backed companies with at least one female founder was stuck at around 17 percent.

Of the US$85 billion that VCs invested globally in 2017, all-women founding teams received US$1.9 billion – a mere three percent of the total amount.

Despite these hurdles, however, the case for female founders is strong. Studies have suggested that female-led businesses improve investors’ fund performance. They’ve also been found to outperform male-led companies by 63 percent in terms of investor returns.

15. Ai Ching Goh, co-founder and CEO, Piktochart – Malaysia

Goh decided to start her own company after failing to fit in cultures of the organizations she had worked for. One day in 2011, she wrote on a piece of paper: “No more Monday blues” – four words that led her to co-found a design studio with developer Andrea Zaggia.

The duo began creating designs for clients, but eventually realized that what they really wanted was to give more people the ability to create appealing visuals.

That same year, Goh and Zaggia founded Piktochart. Piktochart offers a web app that allows non-designers to produce professional-standard infographics.

It now has more than 3.8 million users who have collectively created over 9 million infographics using the platform’s themed templates.

Total funding amount: Undisclosed

Latest fundraise: US$150,000 seed round in October 2012

14. Andrea Loubier, co-founder and CEO, Mailbird – Indonesia

Andrea Loubier is half-American and half-Filipino, but she spent half of her life in Thailand and Indonesia. She started Mailbird as a bootstrapped company in Bali in 2012. Since then, it has gained more than a million users and was awarded the best email client for Windows by PC World and IT World.

Mailbird unifies messages from email, calendar, messaging, task management, and other platforms into a single app. Companies offering a similar product include Nylas and Postbox.

Total funding amount: Undisclosed

13. Nabilah Alsagoff, Founder and chief operating officer, Doku – Indonesia

Nabilah Alsagoff, founder and COO of Doku

After a 2002 terrorist attack in Bali, Alsagoff worked with the local tourism board to help the island recover. She encountered a Malaysian company that supported online payments for hotel bookings and rebuilding efforts, and got the idea for Doku, which she officially set up in 2007.

Doku provides electronic payment and risk management solutions to ecommerce merchants. Within seven years of operations, the company had processed more than US$1.6 billion in payments. At present, it supports more than 2 million users and 35,000 merchants.

In May 2017, Indonesian media conglomerate Emtek Group acquired Doku.

12. Dana von der Heide, founder and chief commercial officer, Parcel Perform – Singapore

Southeast Asia’s robust ecommerce industry has given rise to new business needs, such as tracking deliveries.

Von der Heide used to work with carrier DHL, and helped establish its ecommerce division globally. This gave her insight into the logistical problems that ecommerce companies often encounter, such as how to track their parcels.

Parcel Perform provides such a solution, covering 598 carriers worldwide and generating tracking reports in more than 20 languages.

Total funding amount: US$1.5 million

Latest fundraise: US$1.1 million seed round led by Wavemaker Partners in 2018

11. Nicki Ramsay, founder and CEO, CardUp – Singapore

Prior to starting CardUp, Ramsay was a management consultant at Deloitte Consulting and held roles focused on Asia Pacific at American Express, where she was director of consumer insights and director of international business development for the region.

CardUp allows individuals and businesses to pay for big, recurring expenses, such as rent, with their credit cards – even if the recipient doesn’t accept card payments. Users benefit by maximizing their credit card points and rewards.

Ramsay started the company partly because she was frustrated about not being able to use her credit card to pay for large expenses. Through her banking experience, she also saw how difficult it can be to increase credit card usage.

Total funding amount: US$1.7 million

Latest fundraise: US$1.7 million seed round led by Sequoia Capital and SeedPlus in March 2018

10. Gillian Tee, co-founder and CEO, Homage – Singapore

Singapore has an elderly population of around 450,000, which is set to double by 2030.

Tee and her co-founders, Lily Phang and Tong Duong, saw the need to provide in-home elderly care. In 2016, they launched Homage, a platform that matches the elderly with caregivers and allows on-demand booking.

Total funding amount: US$5.4 million

Latest fundraise: US$4.2 million series A led by HealthXCapital and Golden Gate Ventures in July 2018

9. Roshni Mahtani, founder and CEO, Tickled Media – Singapore

Mahtani transformed her parenting blog into Tickled Media, an online platform that offers services focused on content creation, video production, and display advertising as well as market research. It also has an app and holds community events and conferences.

Headquartered in Singapore, Tickled Media publishes theAsianparent.com, AsianMoneyGuide.com, Parenttown.com, and several women-centric publications. The company reaches over 12 million mothers a month.

Roshni also set up the Female Founders Network, which is now said to have over 2,000 female founders.

Total funding amount: US$7.3 million

Latest fundraise: US$5 million series B led by Global Grand Leisure in May 2018

8. Vivy Yusof, co-founder, FashionValet – Malaysia

After studying law at the London School of Economics, Yusof returned home to Malaysia, where she was a well-known lifestyle blogger. There, she found that the pleasure of shopping was often marred by traffic and the need to drive from on shop to another.

These challenges fueled her decision to start online boutique FashionValet in 2010 – a time when online shopping was still an emerging trend in the country.

FashionValet’s unique proposition lies in ready-to-wear clothing created by local high-end designers. It has since expanded to carry products from more than 500 Southeast Asian designers.

While Yusof found an early customer base among her blog followers, FashionValet now ships to buyers around the world.

In 2016, FashionValet earned an estimated revenue of almost RM40 million (US$9.6 million). More than half of sales came from Malaysia, followed by Singapore and Brunei.

Total funding amount: US$6.4 million

Latest fundraise: Undisclosed amount of series C funding, led by Khazanah Nasional in March 2018

7.  Rachel Lim and Viola Tan, co-founders, Love Bonito – Singapore

Love, Bonito co-founder Rachel Lim / Photo credit: Love, Bonito

In 2005, Lim, along with Tan and her sister Velda, started a blogshop called Bonito Chico as a way to earn extra pocket money. They started out by selling second-hand clothes, but eventually decided to turn their side hustle into a full-blown business.

In 2010, they rebranded as e-tailer Love Bonito, and also began designing original clothing. Velda left in 2013 and has since started her own label, Collate.

Today, Love, Bonito delivers at least 5,000 parcels weekly.

Total funding amount: Unknown

Latest fundraise: US$13 million series B led by Kakaku.com in January 2018

6. Teresa Condicion, co-founder and chief data officer, Snapcart – Indonesia

Finalists at Millennial 20:20, with Snapcart co-founder Teresa Condicion taking center stage.

Indonesian cashback app Snapcart invites users to upload photos of their receipts and get a rebate in exchange. It then uses the collected data to offer data science services to companies in the consumer goods industry.

Condicion, who has 20 years of experience in data analytics across Asia established Snapcart in 2015 together with co-founders Reynazran Royono and Laith Abu Rakty. The app, which has since expanded to the Philippines, was primarily designed to bridge the consumer data gap between online tech and brick-and-mortar retail.

Total funding amount: US$14.7 million

Latest fundraise: US$10 million series A led by Vickers Venture Partners in October 2017

5. Josephine Chow,  co-founder and head of expansion, ShopBack – Singapore

Josephine Chow, co-founder and Head of Market Expansion, ShopBack

Chow was introduced to the startup scene around six years ago, when a friend encouraged her to apply for a job at German incubator Rocket Internet. At the time, she had just ended her post-graduation work holiday trip and had no plans.

Her work at Rocket Internet piqued her interest in the e-commerce industry. In 2015, she joined the ShopBack founded team, which comprises Bryan Chua, Henry Chan, Joel Leong, and Lai Shanru.

Founded in 2014, ShopBack offers shoppers up to 30 percent cashback on all online purchases as well as access to coupons. Around 1,500 retailers use its platform, including major ecommerce players Lazada, Shopee, Taobao, and Zalora.

ShopBack has operations in Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Taiwan and Australia. More than 7 million registered users reportedly place more than 1.5 million orders through the platform. It also claims to have given more than US$25 million in cashback to customers.

Total funding amount: Close to USD40M (https://www.techinasia.com/shopback-25m-funding)

Latest fundraise: US$25 million series A led by Credit Saison in November 2017

4. Rosaline Chow Koo, founder and CEO, CXA Group – Singapore

Rosaline Chow Koo, founder and CEO of CXA. Photo credit: Tech in Asia.

Established in 2013, ConneXionsAsia (CXA) Group offers an online platform that aggregates a network of insurance, healthcare, and wellness providers. It lets employees choose from a range of benefits and protection offered by different companies, based on a budget given by their employer.

Koo oversaw operations in 14 countries during her stint with Mercer Marsh Benefits, an employee benefits brokerage firm, from 2004 to 2012. She invested her entire life savings of US$5 million and borrowed the same amount to purchase Singapore insurance brokerage Pan Group and found CXA.

Today, Google Malaysia, American Express, and other Fortune 500 companies in various sectors are among CXA’s clients. A profitable company valued at more than US$100 million, CXA counts Maxwell Health and Maestro Health as its competitors.

Total funding amount: US$33 million

Latest fundraise: US$25 million in series B led by EDBI and B Capital Group in February 2017

3. Pranoti Nagarkar-Israni, co-founder, Zimplistic – Singapore

Rotimatic founder Pranoti Nagarkar and her husband. Image courtesy Rotimatic

A mechanical engineer, Israni had always wanted to create her own product. She ended up making one that would have an impact on people’s everyday lives: the Rotimatic, an automated roti-making machine.

As the digital counter on its  website shows, Rotimatics around the world have been put to good use, producing 27.6 million rotis and counting.

Zimplistic, the company Israni co-founded with her husband Rishi in 2008 to produce Rotimatic, hit a revenue of US$20 million within a year. Rishi developed the software that powers the appliance, turning it into an internet of things device that can detect the type of flour poured inside. Rotimatic’s 15 sensors work together to churn out a thin, round, puffy flatbread.

Total funding amount: US$48.5 million

Latest fundraise: US$30 million in a series C led by EDBI and Credence Partners in April 2018

2. Ankiti Bose, co-founder and CEO, Zilingo – Singapore

Zilingo co-founder and CEO Ankiti Bose / Photo credit: Zilingo

After Bose studied mathematics and economics, she began her  career in venture capital and management consulting. A trip to Thailand, however, revealed the opportunity to help thousands of small shops sell their products online.

She then founded Zilingo in 2015 as a mobile-first online marketplace for clothing and beauty products, catering to both businesses and consumers. It operates in Indonesia, Singapore, and Thailand, and ships to those countries as well as Australia, Hong Kong, and Malaysia.

More than 10,000 merchants across Asia offer their products on Zilingo. The company is recognized as one of the fastest-growing ecommerce players in Southeast Asia, having grown its revenue elevenfold since it started.

According to Owler, Zilingo’s main competitors include Lazada, Reebonz, and Zalora.

Total funding amount: US$81.9 million

Latest fundraise: US$54 million in series C led by Sofina, Burda Principal Investments, and Sequoia Capital India in April 2018

1.  Hooi Ling Tan, co-founder and chief operating officer, Grab – Malaysia

GrabPay head Jason Thompson (L), Nornizam Bin Amin of Rayyan’s Waroeng Penyet (M),
and Grab co-founder Tan Hooi Ling at the launch of GrabPay QR code payments. Photo credit: Grab.

Southeast Asia’s leading ride-hailing platform needs little introduction. With an average of 4 million daily rides and diversified services – including payments and express courier – Grab is on its way to becoming a super app.

A former McKinsey consultant, Tan co-founded GrabTaxi along with Anthony Tan, one of her classmates at Harvard. They entered their concept in in a business plan contest held by the university in 2011 and were named as runners-up. After a brief stint at Salesforce, Tan returned to Malaysia in 2015 to work on Grab full time. She is currently the company’s chief operating officer.

Total funding amount: US$6.1 billion

Latest fundraise: US$1 billion from a series H led by Toyota in August 2018

seo.title: 15 female founders smashing the glass ceiling in the region
seo.description: Studies have suggested that female-led businesses improve investors’ fund performance. They’ve also been found to outperform male-led companies by 63 percen
